STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 12, 2019
Kristie Hardin
Catholic Charities of Southeast Michigan
17500 W 8 Mile
Southfield, MI 48075
RE: License #: CB630201423
Catholic Charities of Southeast Michigan
17500 W 8 Mile
Southfield, MI 48075
Dear Ms. Hardin:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
03/05/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the and
your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license license will be
issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will
result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB630201423
Licensee Name: Catholic Charities of Southeast Michigan
Licensee Address: 18688 Joann
Detroit, MI 48205
Licensee Telephone #:
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jason Shanks, Designee
Name of Facility: Catholic Charities of Southeast Michigan
Facility Address: 17500 W 8 Mile
Southfield, MI 48075
Facility Telephone #: (248) 552-0750
Original Issuance Date: 03/29/1993
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s):02/20/2019, 02/21/2019,02/26/2019, 03/01/2019 & 03/05/2019

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
Two of eight new employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record showed two of three references were not
dated and it could not be discerned if the references were
received before the employee’s 11/19/18 date of hire.
 A second record contained only two references.
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of eight new employee records reviewed showed the
employee’s probationary evaluation was thirteen days late.
Repeat Violation Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(b) Identification of the information source, unless
anonymous or confidential, as specified in the child protection
law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
One of ten special evaluations reviewed showed the birth
mother’s name and indicated the birth parent as the source.
(e) Findings of fact based upon the evaluation.
One of ten special investigations reviewed did not document
clear findings of facts based upon evidence in the evaluation.
4

R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report required
by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a
right to have his or her written response included as an
attachment to the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
Two of ten special investigations reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rule.
R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
Three of ten special investigations reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Interim 2016.
R400.12418 Development of services plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of twenty-eight updated service plans reviewed was thirty-
two days late.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
R400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Two of five adoptive evaluations reviewed did not show
compliance as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017.
5

R400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption with a
signed and dated copy of the evaluation and recommendation
upon its completion.
One of five adoptive family evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation that a copy of the family’s 8/23/18 evaluation
was provided.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP A violation. Please note that
there are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the
following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
Five of seven open child records, one of three closed child
records, and one of three open independent living youth records
reviewed did not show consistent documentation that each
signed service plans and signed parent/agency treatment plan
agreements, medical passport, 3600 or family team meeting
(FTM)- DHS-1105 were uploaded to MISACWIS.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017.
ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight (Commitment 66).
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on
the worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve
each service plan. The plan can be approved only after the
supervisor has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which
can be the monthly meeting
Seven of twenty-eight service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of a face-to-face supervisor/worker meeting prior
to signing the service plan. The meeting was either in the
6

month before the plan was signed or the month or date after it
was signed.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016-
Cite under MSA.
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
One of twenty-eight service plans reviewed, where the youth
was fourteen years or older, did not contain the youth’s
signature.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016-
Cite under MSA.
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, and
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Four of seven open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that the medical passport was consistently
updated quarterly. One of these related to a case the caregiver
informed the Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL)
Analyst he never received the medical passport. Case
documentation showed the caregiver signed a medical passport
and an acknowledgement form of receipt of each child’s medical
passport on 8/10/18 the date the agency assumed the case. A
medical passport for the next two quarters is not documented.
In a fifth case, the children’s caregiver informed the DCWL
Analyst she did not receive the medical passport. Agency case
7

documentation showed the caregiver signed placement
documentation on 2/7/18 acknowledging receipt of each child’s
medical passport. The caregiver also signed a medical
passport for one child on 2/8/18 and the other child on 3/14/18.
However, quarterly passports thereafter are not documented.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016-
Cited under MSA.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
Policy FOM 722- Family Team Meeting.
6 B
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as out-lined in the following tables…
 Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Three of twenty-eight service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of an FTM for the service plan periods as
required by the standard.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Caseworker Contacts.
6H
Unannounced Home visit.
8

The caseworker must make an unannounced visit to the
placement every quarter. This unannounced visit must be noted
in the social work contacts of the case service plan.
Two of seven open child records and one of three open
independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of a quarterly unannounced home visit to the
licensed foster parent/caregiver/youth’s placement for a
specified quarterly period.
In a third case the caregiver informed the DCWL Analyst only a
couple of unannounced home visits occurred since the children
have been in her care. The record showed unannounced home
visits as required except for one service period.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Case contact.
6H
Quality Visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have been
found to produce positive outcomes for children in foster care. A
quality visit is defined as one in which the caseworker:
 Meets with each child individually, without the presence of
other individuals to give the child an opportunity to ask
questions or to ensure safe sleep requirements are followed.
 Assesses each child’s needs and takes appropriate action or
offers services in response to the identified need of each child.
 Shows interest in the child to build and establish rapport.
 Shares and explains the case plan in a developmentally
appropriate way while allowing the child to ask questions and
express viewpoints.
One of seven open child records reviewed, and one three open
independent living youth records reviewed did not show detail
information related to one and two respective home visits with
the child/youth.
A third open child record did not show documentation that all
face-to-face contacts were listed in the child’s 10/30/18-1/25/19
USP.
9

Policy FOM 722- Foster Care - Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service
8C Agreement.
Signatures:
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
Two of twenty-eight service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of the foster parent/caregiver’s signature.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Updated Service Plan.
9
Supervisory Approval:
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report.
Four of twenty-eight USP(s) were late by:
 Seven days.
 Ten days.
 Eleven days.
 Thirty-one days.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2018, Renewal 2017, Interim 2016.
Policy FOM 913- Placement Resources: Child Placing Agency Reporting
4 Requirements.
Case Closure/Transfer:
Within three business days of case closure or an agency
transfer, the PAFC worker must prepare and submit a DHS-69,
Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, including a
narrative termination summary and the reason for termination to
all of the following individuals/entities:
One of three closed child records reviewed showed the child’s
1/30/19 action summary was completed over two months after
the child’s 11/12/18 date of termination.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2016.
10

CI 16-182a Communication Issuance.
Security Awareness Training for Fingerprint Base Criminal
History Requirements.
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based
Criminal History Record Information (CHRI). This training
provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
Security Awareness Training is required to be completed no
later than Tuesday February 10, 2017 for all non-contracted and
governmental CPA employees, subcontractors, subcontractor’s
employees or volunteers who are authorized to have access to
fingerprint-based CHRI.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
are authorized to have access to fingerprint-based CHRI must
successfully complete SAT within six months of appointment to
a position with CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
One of ten current employees listed as having access to CHRI
did not show documentation the employee completed the
required training by the 2/10/17 due date.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12420 (c) & (f) Updated service plan
Caregiver input and information received from the caregiver shall be clearly
indicated and updated from the previous service plan.
ISEP. 649 Medical passports
The agency is advised the worker and caregiver shall consistently date the medical
passport.
Policy FOM 722-8C Foster Care - Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement.
The agency is advised the caregiver shall consistently date the parent-agency
treatment plan and service agreement.
11

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12312(5) Foster parent training.
Uploading/maintaining a training log with proof of the foster parent training hours
may aid in showing clear documentation of required trainings for the period.
R400.12510(1)(d) Independent living contract.
Adding a line to the agency’s independent living contract form to install the youth’s
living location may aid the agency in showing ongoing compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2018 Interim inspection where it
received a number of rule, ISEP, and policy violations. The agency made
substantial gains in all areas of its corrective action plan. The number of overall
citations were reduced.
The agency reported various department changes. The agency remains under the
leadership of the same chief administrator, but since the last inspection, it has
experienced several staff changes. The agency’s family services unit and child
welfare program merged and are under the guidance of this chief administrator. One
foster care worker and adoption worker switched roles. In October 2018 the adoption
supervisor was promoted to program manager, and she oversees foster care,
licensing and adoption. An adoption staff was promoted to adoption supervisor.
Additionally, six new workers, five in foster care and one in adoption joined the
agency. The agency reported it is adjusting well to these staff changes.
DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS ADDRESSED:
Safety Alert #1: No concerns identified.
Safety Alert #2: No concerns identified.
Safety Alert #3: No concerns identified.
12

Safety Alert #4:
Concern:
Caregiver reported that the foster care worker hasn’t made any unannounced home
visits.
Resolution:
The agency assumed case responsibility on 8/10/18 and an unannounced home visit
occurred 9/18/18. However, an unannounced home visit was not documented for
the service period 11/15/18-2/12/18. The agency received a citation under Policy
related to unannounced home visits.
Concern:
The caregiver reported never receiving the medical passport.
Resolution:
The case record/MISACWIS showed the caregiver was provided a copy of the
children’s medical passport on 8/10/18. A quarterly updated medical passport was
not completed thereafter. The agency was cited under ISEP for medical passport.
Safety Alert #5:
Concern:
The caregiver reported not participating in a Family Team Meeting.
Resolution:
The caregiver participated in family team meetings (FTM) in-person and via telephone.
FTM activity reports contain the caregiver’s signature showing her participation.
Concern:
The caregiver reported that the foster care worker made 3-4 unannounced home visits
since the child’s placement.
Resolution:
The worker completed all required unannounced home visits except for the service
period 4/8/18-7/5/18. The agency received a violation under Policy for unannounced
home visits.
Concern:
The caregiver reported the child hasn’t received all needed services. They reported
asking for an IEP for the foster child and hasn’t received it to date.
Resolution:
The child had an initial IEP on 4/10/18. In September of 2018 the caregiver changed
the child’s school without informing the agency, but the IEP has followed the child to the
new school. The agency has made attempts to have the IEP updated. The school
personnel to execute this is on maternity leave. The agency is following up on this.
13

Concern:
There are no monthly sibling visitation taking place.
Resolution:
The child is a permanent ward. MISACWIS showed the youngest sibling is placed with
the birth parent and the other two listed siblings are adults.
Safety Alert #6:
Concern:
The caregiver reported not receiving the medical passport.
Resolution:
The caregiver signed documentation on 2/7/18 acknowledging receipt of each child’s
medical passport. The caregiver also signed a medical passport for one child on 2/8/18
and the other child on 3/14/18. However, quarterly medical passports thereafter are not
documented. The agency received a violation under ISEP for medical passports.
Concern:
The caregiver reported that the foster care worker had made only a couple of
unannounced home visits since the foster children have been in care.
Resolution:
The record showed unannounced home visits as required except for one service period.
The agency received a violation under Policy for unannounced home visits.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
March 11, 2019
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 12, 2019
_______________________________________
Date
Area Manager
14
